race.name: WYO 131
race.tagline: Central Wyoming ultra-distance gravel through mountain and high desert.

vitals.aid_stations: Multiple aid stations for ultra distance

climate.description: High altitude with variable conditions. Wind and sun exposure.

terrain.primary: Wyoming mountain and high desert gravel
terrain.surface: Mix of mountain and high desert gravel roads. Significant elevation with remote wilderness setting.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional ultra-distance event. 131 miles is serious challenge but regional field and infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: WYO 131 offers a genuine ultra-distance challenge—131 miles through Wyoming mountain and high desert terrain. It's a well-organized regional ultra event with good support, but the field is regional and it's remote central Wyoming. The adventure of riding through Wind River Range country is the main appeal, along with the ultra-distance challenge.
strengths: Beautiful Wyoming mountain and desert scenery
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional ultra-distance gravel race with genuine Wyoming wilderness appeal. Worth it for Wyoming cyclists or those seeking an ultra-distance challenge in the Rockies. Not a destination race for distant travelers, but a good regional ultra event.

final_verdict.one_liner: Regional Wyoming ultra-distance through mountain and high desert.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Wyoming or the Rockies and want an ultra-distance challenge—yes, it's a well-organized event with genuine wilderness appeal. If you're traveling from far away—there are more prestigious ultra events elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better ultra-distance: Unbound XL (Kansas), Dirty Kanza. For similar regional ultras: other Rocky Mountain ultra events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Lander has basic lodging. Small city with limited options. Book early.
logistics.food: Small city with basic dining. Stock nutrition for ultra distance.

history.origin_story: Ultra-distance gravel event in central Wyoming.

course_description.character: Mix of mountain and high desert terrain through Wyoming wilderness.

suffering_zones.label: First Third
suffering_zones.desc: 40 miles in, settling into ultra pace.

course_description.signature_challenge: 131-mile ultra-distance at high altitude through Wyoming wilderness.

guide_variables.race_terrain: Wyoming mountain and high desert gravel

non_negotiables.why: 131 miles requires extensive endurance base and ultra-distance preparation.
Racing at 6000-8000+ feet requires altitude acclimatization or preparation.
Ultra-distance success depends on conservative pacing and not going out too hard.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 131 miles of Wyoming mountain and high desert gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional ultra-distance challenge through Wind River Range country.

logistics.explanation: Race-day packet pickup from 5:30-7:30 AM for a 6 AM start cuts it close for 131 miles of Wyoming backcountry. Registration has tripled in three years according to race director Gwen Robson, but no airport, lodging, or parking details are provided for riders figuring out remote Lander.

length.explanation: 131 miles with 10,000 feet of climbing delivered a 23% DNF rate in 2024—12 of 52 starters in the men's race couldn't finish. Winner Chris Mehlman's 7:04 time versus 40th place Nicholas Valoff's 13:24 shows the full spectrum of suffering across this distance.

technicality.explanation: The course is explicitly described as 'top-tier gravel roads (no sketchy two-track here!)' and 'fast, flowy, and ridiculously fun.' The YouTube channel addresses tire size recommendations yearly, but the focus is endurance over technical bike handling through this high desert terrain.

elevation.explanation: The course 'stacks up 10,000 feet of vert' climbing from sagebrush plateaus to Wind River subalpine terrain before the 'wicked, white-knuckle descent through Sinks Canyon State Park.' This vertical gain spans multiple ecosystems from desert floor to high alpine lakes.

climate.explanation: September conditions are described as variable—'Conditions change every year' per the official YouTube channel, creating 'sandy desert, chunky climbs, high alpine bliss' scenarios. The 6 AM lights-required start suggests weather window concerns at this Wyoming altitude.

altitude.explanation: Starting around 7,500 feet in Lander, riders climb to 'subalpine terrain' in the Wind River Mountains, likely cresting over 10,000 feet. The course description emphasizes sustained altitude exposure through 'high alpine bliss' rather than brief elevation spikes.

adventure.explanation: The route delivers 'pure, untamed adventure' through 'towering hoodoos' and 'historic mining towns frozen in time' before reaching subalpine lakes. Described as 'Type-2 fun at its finest' with crew-accessible bail points when Wyoming backcountry adventure exceeds rider capability.

prestige.explanation: Chris Mehlman's 7:04 course record reflects a small competitive field without major pro presence. Race director Gwen Robson notes registration has tripled but emphasizes preserving the 'intimate small-town gravel race' feel over building national recognition.

race_quality.explanation: The course earns its reputation as 'one of the toughest gravel races in the U.S.' with cutoffs at Hudson, Highway 789, and Atlantic City that actually matter—23% DNF rate proves it. Race-day-only packet pickup and limited logistics keep it from premium execution standards.

experience.explanation: Lander is 'ranked as one of the best outdoor towns in the U.S.' and 'known worldwide for rock climbing and mountain biking.' The course spans desert to alpine terrain, but missing weather data and sparse logistical details leave experience quality partly to chance.

community.explanation: Post-race features live music from Low Water String Band, local BBQ from Bunk's, and Push Root Brewery beer. The 'Ride hard. Live easy. Wave often' ethos embodies 'small-town, friendly Wyoming spirit' with kids' push-bike races expanding the community feel.

field_depth.explanation: The men's 131-mile had 52 starters with a 13+ hour spread from winner to 40th place, indicating limited competitive depth. Women's field had only 9 finishers, suggesting small overall participation despite the race director noting tripled registration growth.

value.explanation: Four distance options from 13 to 131 miles serve different rider levels, with the kids' push-bike race adding family value. Post-race party includes local BBQ and brewery beer, though missing entry fee data makes cost-benefit analysis impossible.

expenses.explanation: Lander offers 'art galleries, bike shops, and the best ice cream west of the Mississippi' but no specific lodging costs available. The tire size video suggests gear considerations vary annually, potentially adding equipment expenses for this remote Wyoming destination.
